Review The role of strain in oxygen evolution reaction Zihang Feng a Chuanlin Dai a Zhe Zhang a Xuefei Lei a Wenning Mu a Rui Guo a Xuanwen Liu a ⁎ Junhua You b ⁎ a School of Materials Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, Shenyang 110819, Liaoning, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Northeastern University Shenyang Liaoning 110819 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, Shenyang 110819, Liaoning, China b School of Materials Science and Technology, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang 110870, Liaoning, China School of Materials Science and Technology Shenyang University of Technology Shenyang Liaoning 110870 China School of Materials Science and Technology, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang 110870, Liaoning, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract At present, strain is widely used in OER, but there is no systematic review of the role of strain. This review describes the theoretical principles of strain, the introduction of strain and the role of strain, and gives some suggestions for better development of this field. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a crucial step in metal-air batteries and water splitting technologies, playing a significant role in the efficiency and achievable heights of these two technologies. However, the OER is a four-step, four-electron reaction, and its slow kinetics result in high overpotentials, posing a challenge. To address this issue, numerous strategies involving modified catalysts have been proposed and proven to be highly efficient. In these strategies, the introduction of strain has been widely reported because it is generally believed to effectively regulate the electronic structure of metal sites and alter the adsorption energy of catalyst surfaces with reaction intermediates. However, strain has many other effects that are not well known, making it an important yet unexplored area. Based on this, this review provides a detailed introduction to the various roles of strain in OER. To better explain these roles, the review also presents the definition of strain and elucidates the potential mechanisms of strain in OER based on the d-band center theory and adsorption volcano plot. Additionally, the review showcases various ways of introducing strain in OER through examples reported in the latest literature, aiming to provide a comprehensive perspective for the development of strain engineering. Finally, the review analyzes the appropriate proportion of strain introduction, compares compressive and tensile strain, and examines the impact of strain on stability. And the review offers prospects for future research directions in this emerging field. Keywords Oxygen evolution reaction Strain generation Tensile strain Compressive strain Strain mechanism Strain effects 1 Introduction Since the Industrial Revolution, human development has heavily relied on non-renewable energy sources. While the use of these non-renewable energy sources has fueled global industrialization, it has also inflicted severe damage to the global environment [1–4]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to find alternative sources of energy. Currently, humanity has explored some new renewable energy sources such as solar energy, wind energy, and tidal energy. However, these energy sources are not stable as they are dependent on seasons or regions [5,6]. Therefore, it is necessary to propose other solutions, and the conversion of renewable energy into fuels or chemicals is a viable option. Among the proposed solutions, hydrogen gas has gained attention due to its high energy density, ease of storage and transportation, and environmentally friendly characteristics [7–9]. Currently, industrial hydrogen production is primarily achieved through steam reforming of methane or gasification of coal, resulting in low purity of H2 and the production of CO2 as a byproduct of the reaction. In addition, producing hydrogen through water electrolysis is an environmentally friendly solution, as it can yield high-purity hydrogen at room temperature. Water electrolysis consists of two half-reactions: the cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER), as described in Eqs. (1) and (2) respectively [10–12]. (1) H E R : 2 e - + 2 H + → H 2 (2) O E R : 2 H 2 O → 4 H + + O 2 + 4 e - Electrolyzing water cannot be done directly, it requires an additional voltage. Under ideal conditions, this voltage is 1.23 V. However, in practical applications, the required voltage is much higher than 1.23 V. The HER is a two-step, two-electron process that is relatively straightforward [13–15]. On the other hand, the OER is a four-step, four-electron process that involves the adsorption and desorption of various reaction intermediates, ultimately resulting in the production of oxygen [16,17]. Therefore, an additional voltage is needed to overcome the energy barrier during the reaction, and catalysts can help lower this voltage. Developing an efficient, cost-effective, and stable OER catalyst is a challenge that needs to be addressed [18–21]. Noble-metal-based compounds such as IrO2 and RuO2 are considered as the most efficient OER catalysts and serve as the standard for evaluating other OER catalysts. However, their scarcity and high cost make them impractical for commercialization. Therefore, it is necessary to identify alternative materials that can serve as OER electrocatalysts. These alternative materials should exhibit excellent catalytic stability, high catalytic efficiency, and abundant reserves [22–24]. Transition metal compounds [25,26], including layered-double-hydroxides (LDH) [27,28], oxides [29,30], sulfides etc. [7], due to their exceptional electrocatalytic properties and convenient synthesis methods, these materials have gained significant attention and made substantial progress in various fields. Additionally, there have been significant advancements in improving the oxygen evolution dynamics of metal alloys [31–33], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [34,35], and perovskites [36,37], which have further enhanced the reliability of electrocatalyst screening. Extensive efforts have been devoted to enhancing the electrocatalytic performance of potential competitors through various strategies, including heterogeneous atoms doping [38,39], interface engineering construction [40,41], controlled morphology [42,43], particle size control [44,45], and vacancy defect implantation [46]. These approaches involve manipulating the electronic states and geometric properties of the catalyst promoting charge transfer, modulating the oxidation states of elements, and optimizing the energy of adsorption/desorption of reactants and intermediates, thereby achieving better catalytic activity. Among these strategies, the introduction of strain engineering has been demonstrated to significantly enhance catalytic activity, which is of great technological significance in the innovative design of electrocatalysts [47–50]. Introducing strain to enhance catalytic activity in catalysts is undoubtedly an efficient approach. This method has been fundamentally and extensively proven to be feasible and important [51,52]. Strain is the deformation of a solid caused by stress, which is defined as the external force acting on a unit area. Elastic deformation, also known as elastic strain, is reversible [53], while plastic deformation, also known as plastic strain, is irreversible. Due to the significant lattice distortion caused by plastic deformation, which can disrupt the original electronic structure of the material, it is usually not introduced into catalysts. Depending on the applied stress, catalysts can be categorized into tensile strain or compressive strain, where tensile strain elongates the catalyst while compressive strain shortens it [54–56]. The catalytic activity of a catalyst can be influenced by both tensile and compressive strains, offering the potential for improved practical applications. This review provides a detailed introduction to the various roles of strain in OER. To better explain these roles, the review also presents the definition of strain and elucidates the potential mechanisms of strain in OER based on the d-band center theory and adsorption volcano plot. Additionally, the review showcases various ways of introducing strain in OER through examples reported in the latest literature, aiming to provide a comprehensive perspective for the development of strain engineering. Finally, this review analyzes the factors that need to be focus when applying adaptation to OER, and provides an outlook on future research directions in this field. 2 Theory principles of strain The intrinsic electronic and physicochemical properties of an electrocatalyst play a crucial role in determining its activity and reaction kinetics. To understand these properties, it is important to consider the interaction strength (adsorption/desorption) between the catalyst surface and the reactants/intermediates, as it provides valuable information about the catalyst's activity and kinetics. Unfortunately, there is currently no experimental method available to directly measure the binding energy between the catalyst surface and intermediates [57,58]. This limitation makes it challenging to establish a quantitative correlation between the material properties and the electrochemical performance. However, advancements in computational quantum chemistry, specifically DFT calculations based on the first-principles, have provided a viable approach to investigate the interaction between the catalyst and the intermediates. Theoretical research using DFT has enabled us to uncover intricate details of the mechanisms behind numerous chemical reactions. By calculating energies, we can illustrate the fluctuations in free energy during electrocatalytic processes, providing insights into the energy landscapes of chemical reactions. This allows us to identify the specific intermediate steps that act as rate-limiting factors in the overall reaction process. Through the analysis of the energy landscape, we can explain the occurrence of overpotential phenomena in existing catalytic systems, determine the intermediate step(s) that impose limitations on the entire reaction process, and provide a rationale for the utilization of strain to fine-tune the energetics The upcoming sections will present the adsorption energy and the rate-volcano plot, the d-band center theory, which could provide guidance in the development of advanced electrocatalysts for high-efficiency OER [59–61]. 2.1 The simple definition of strain Lattice-strain, a fundamental physicochemical property of materials, plays a crucial role in electrocatalysis. In general, lattice-strain refers to the deviation from the equilibrium spacing between atoms in the crystal lattice of nanomaterials. The strain (ε) is determined by calculating the change in lattice parameter (a strained) relative to the unstrained original (a original) using Eq. (3) [62]. (3) ε = a strainded - a original a original × 100 % Eq. (3) can accurately assess the level of compressive/tensile strain occurring within or on the surface of the nanocatalyst. 2.2 The adsorption energy and the rate-volcano plot Once we have determined the reaction mechanisms using density functional theory (DFT), we can establish scaling relations between the binding energies of intermediates. These relations allow us to create a simplified model that provides a concise description of the overall reaction rate. This model is often represented graphically as a volcano plot, which resembles the shape of a volcano. The highest point on the volcano represents the fastest reaction rate. Therefore, this approach helps us design optimal catalysts by modifying the binding energies of intermediates to position them near the peak of the volcano plot [63–65]. Different catalytic systems are situated at various positions along the HER or OER volcano. In a study led by Nørskov and colleagues, they created an acidic HER rate-volcano by performing hydrogen binding energy calculations on various catalytic surfaces, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). The peak of the volcano is occupied by surfaces such as Pt, Re, Pd, Ir, and Rh, which have been confirmed through experiments to be highly efficient HER catalysts [66].The correlation between experimental results and theoretical predictions highlights the ability of DFT to capture the underlying trends among transition-metal surfaces in HER electrocatalysis (as shown in Fig. 1a). Furthermore, Fig. 1(b) provides significant insights into the HER reaction, particularly the three elementary steps: Volmer, Heyrovsky, and Tafel. It reveals that the binding energy of H correlated with the activation energy required for the formation of H2 gas. A weaker H binding energy corresponds to a higher barrier for H2 formation, while a stronger H binding energy is associated with a lower barrier. It is important to note that a stronger H binding energy could potentially lead to surface poisoning caused by adsorbed hydrogen. In a similar vein, researchers have uncovered a universal scaling relation between *OH and *OOH in the OER, as illustrated in Fig. 1(c and d) [67]. As a result, we can construct a volcano plot (as shown in Fig. 1e and f) that illustrates how the overpotential for the OER is determined by the disparity in binding energy between *OH and *OOH. If there is a difference of 1.23 eV in binding energy, the reaction would have zero overpotential. Hence, to optimize OER performance, it is necessary to identify methods to stabilize *OOH in relation to *OH [51,65]. In short, the scale relationship between binding energy of species can be intermediated by using DFRT, because intermediate species have both adsorption and dissociation processes, so the relationship between binding energy and reaction rate is volcanic. We can find the most suitable binding energy theoretically first, and then adjust the binding energy by introducing strain, so that the catalyst can obtain the fastest reaction rate. 2.3 The d-band center theory Through the use of the d-band center model, we can effectively elucidate the role of strain effects in OER and many other electrocatalytic reactions, making it one of the most successful theories for understanding catalytic activity [68]. The d-band center theory, proposed by Hammer and Nørskov, is used to predict the adsorption capability of reactants and intermediates on the surfaces of metals, metal alloys, and oxides [69]. When an adsorbate binds to the surface of metals, alloys, or oxides, the electrons of the adsorbate interact with the valence bands of s, p, and d orbitals of the catalyst, forming chemical bonds (as depicted in Fig. 1g) [70]. In this process, it is primarily the electrons in the d orbitals of the metal that play a major role in bond formation and strength, as the energies of the s and p orbitals do not undergo significant changes. The orbitals of the adsorbate hybridize with the d orbitals of the metal, resulting in a fully filled bonding molecular orbital (s) and a partially filled antibonding molecular orbital (s*). The energy levels or occupancy of the antibonding orbitals determine the strength of the metal-adsorbate bond. By shifting the d-band center downward, the occupancy of the antibonding orbitals is reduced, leading to a weakening of the metal-adsorbate bond. The bonding energy levels of transition metals exhibit minimal variation, while there is a significant disparity in the antibonding energy levels among different metals. The occupancy of the d-band in early transition metals is less than half, resulting in an opposite dependence of adsorption energy during strain modulation. This contradicts the phenomenon observed in late transition metals, where the d-band center shifts upward to maintain the filling rate of the d-band as the wave function narrows (as depicted in Fig. 1h) [71]. Fig. 1(i) shows that the regulation of lattice strain on the d-band center is influenced by the root-mean-square deviation [51]. The d-band center of early transition metals such as Sc, Ti, and V shifts downward with increasing strain, while late transition metals like Cr and Mn show the opposite trend. However, Zr is unique in that its d-band center shift is not affected by strain. In short, the scale relationship between binding energy of intermediate species can be determined by using DFT, because intermediate species have both adsorption and dissociation processes, so the relationship between binding energy and reaction rate is volcanic. The d-band center theory is used to predict the adsorption capacity of reactants and intermediates on the catalyst surface. We can first find the most suitable binding energy theoretically, and then adjust the binding energy by introducing strain so that it is near the peak value of the volcano diagram, and then, the catalyst can obtain the fastest OER reaction rate. 3 The various method of introducing strain Strain engineering introduces the principles of mechanics, a traditional field, into the realm of electrochemistry. The introduction of strain, encompassing both chemical and physical strain, forms the foundation for studying the effects of strain. The strategies employed for strain can be broadly categorized into physical and chemical methods. The physical method involves introducing strain by applying an external force to a material, while the chemical method involves introducing strain by altering the local lattice structure through doping, alloying, constructing a heterojunction, modulation, epitaxial growth, and other methods., and other means. In the following part, we will introduce them. 3.1 Chemical methods induced strain 3.1.1 Heteroatomic doping induced strain Nowadays, the existing methods to generate lattice strain have been mostly reported to construct lattice mismatch [73], creating heterostructure [74], and preparing ultrathin nanostructures [75]. However, the traditional methods to synthesize the strain-effected electrocatalysts are complex and time-consuming, which hinder the manufacturing efficiency and limit the applications widely. Additionally, some strain induced catalysts could generate to relax the eventually impede the long-term stability and reaction activity [76]. Moreover, the single strain-induced electrocatalysts are still hardly achieve to the high OER/ORR bifunctional performances [77].To overcome these challenges, Zhang [78] developed a novel Pt-NiO@Ni submicron particles (Pt-NiO@Ni SP), as depicted in Fig. 2 (a). The lattice strain is induced by milling the Ni skeleton with a high concentration of defects, using the jet electrodeposition technique. Through a combination of in situ oxidation and a wet process, the Pt and NiO nanoparticles are uniformly integrated into the surface of the Ni-based SP(Ni SP), which is regulated by tensile strain. The HRTEM (high resolution transmission electron microscope) image of the NiO@Ni SP shown in Fig. 2(b) reveals a distinct interface surrounding the surface of the NiO@Ni SP. Interestingly, the lattice spacing within the particles measures 0.204 nm, corresponding to the (111) plane of Ni. However, this value is slightly larger than the lattice spacing of the Ni skeleton (0.202 nm), indicating that the NiO@Ni SP experiences tensile strain in its core, possibly due to the milling process or defects. Additionally, the researchers conducted the same milling process on commercial Ni particles as a control group. The SEM (Scanning Electronic Microscopy) image in Fig. 2(c) displays a uniform sub-micron particle structure. The HRTEM images in Fig. 2(d) reveal that the lattice spacings of the milled Ni particles remain unchanged, still corresponding to the (111) plane, and no lattice structure defects are observed. This suggests that the lattice strain induced in the NiO@Ni SP is caused by defects rather than the milling process, further confirming the crucial role of defects in inducing strain. Furthermore, to further demonstrate the presence of tensile strain in the NiO@Ni SP, measurements of the Ni-K edge expend X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) were conducted by the researchers. Fig. 2(e) illustrates the identification of defects in the Pt-NiO@Ni SP and NiO@Ni SP based on the lower peak intensity of the metallic Ni, which aligns with the HRTEM findings (Fig. 2d). Additionally, the bond length of the Ni-Ni peak in Pt-NiO@Ni SP measures 2.24 Å, similarly to NiO@Ni (2.25 Å) but noticeably longer than Ni foil (2.18 Å). This result indicates the evident presence of tensile strain in the metallic Ni. The primary peak assigned to the Ni-O bond is weak, implying that the crystalline oxide content is significantly lower than the metallic Ni. This further underscores the impact of tensile strain on the metallic Ni. Analysis of the wavelet transform EXAFS contour in Fig. 2(e) reveals that only one peak around 7.5 Å−1 can be attributed to the Ni-Ni contribution in both Pt-NiO@Ni SP and NiO@Ni SP. Moreover, the intensity centers of these samples exhibit a slightly higher value compared to Ni foil, further confirming the existence of tensile strain in the Ni lattice spacing. In addition, Gao [79] utilized DFT calculations to investigate the impact of lattice strain induced by heteroatom doping on the catalytic activities of Co@N1-GY. They synthesized Co,N co-decorated graphyne (Co@N1-GY) and applied both uniaxial and biaxial strain to optimize the catalytic activities for the HER and the OER. They initially selected a series of lattice constants (a and b) for the Co@N1-GY monolayer and optimized these structures under various fixed a/b-uniaxial or biaxial strain conditions (as shown in Fig. 3 h). They found that the Co–C bond length exhibbited a strong linear relationship with the lattice strain (as depicted in Fig. 3d), increasing from 1.89 to 1.95 Å with a biaxial lattice strain ranging from −3% to 3%. Additionally, they plotted the changes in total energy per 2 × 2 supercell after optimization against the lattice strain in Fig. 3(a). All values in Fig. 3(a) were determined relative to the unstrained Co@N1-GY monolayer, which was defined as zero. They observed that within the range of a/b-uniaxial strain from −3% (compressive) to 5% (tensile), or biaxial strain from −3% (compressive) to 3% (tensile), the total energy of the Co@N1-GY monolayer increased with the lattice strain, indicating that the increase in total energy was solely dependent on the presence of strain, regardless of whether it was tensile or compressive. These increased energies of the Co@N1-GY monolayer led to instability, as shown in Fig. 3(b), which was unfavorable for the binding of Co atoms on the substrate. Furthermore, biaxial lattice strain had a stronger effect on the properties of the Co@N1-GY monolayer compared to a/b-uniaxial strain. However, even under the maximum tensile strain (3% for biaxial strain and 5% for a/b-uniaxial strain) and maximum compressive strain (−3% for both biaxial strain and a/b-uniaxial strain), there was still a binding energy of over 2.0 eV for the Co atoms on the substrate, indicating a relatively strong binding strength. However, under higher tensile strain, the binding energy significantly decreased to nearly zero (as shown in Fig. 3e–g), and the structure of Co@N1-GY became distorted under a compressive strain of −4% (as shown in Fig. 3c). 3.1.2 Heterostructure induced strain In most cases, heterostructure catalysts exhibit better OER activity compared to single-component catalysts [80]. This is because heterojunction catalysts have unique hetero-interfaces that enhance electronic transfer between different components and induce lattice strain [81]. Additionally, the generation of lattice strain effectively modulates the adsorption strength of reactant intermediates during the OER process [82]. For this reason, researchers synthesized Ni(OH)2/MoS2 heterostructures, as illustrated in Fig. 4 (a) [83]. They first controlled the formation of Ni2+ and OH− ions, which were subsequently transformed into Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles. Then, Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles were deposited on the surface of MoS2 nanofibers, resulting in the formation of Ni(OH)2/MoS2 heterostructures. Compared to MoS2 nanofibers, the Ni(OH)2/MoS2 nanofiber heterostructures exhibited lower diffraction peak intensities, indicating lower crystallinity attributed to the smaller size of Ni(OH)2. The HRTEM image of MoS2 nanofibers (as depicted in Fig. 4b) revealed the presence of single- and few-layered MoS2 nanofibers with abundant active sites along the edges. The low-magnitude transmission electron microscopy image of Ni(OH)2/MoS2 nanofiber heterostructures, along with the corresponding selected area electron diffraction inset images as depicted in Fig. 4(c), confirmed the coexistence of Ni(OH)2 and MoS2 nanofibers. The HRTEM image (as depicted in Fig. 4d) displayed an irregular hexagonal shape with sharp edges for Ni(OH)2, while Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles were observed to be scattered throughout the MoS2 nanosheets. A lattice fringe with a spacing of 0.23 nm, corresponding to the (101) plane of Ni(OH)2, was observed in Fig. 4(e). After the decoration of Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles on the surface of MoS2 nanofibers, the interlayer spacing of MoS2 nanofibers slightly increased from 0.64 to 0.67 nm (as depicted in Fig. 4f), indicating the formation of the heterostructure and the generation of strain. Strain can be calculated using the following Eq. (4). (4) Strain % = Δ a a The lattice constant “a” is used to calculate the tensile strain. The calculated tensile strain of the Ni(OH)2/MoS2 nanofiber heterostructures was approximately 3.5%. Ni(OH)2 was uniformly decorated on the MoS2 nanofibers, with sizes varying from 3 to 30 nm. This rich decoration of Ni(OH)2 on the layered structure resulted in tensile strain in the zigzag or armchair direction (as depicted in Fig. 4g). In addition, the investigation of strain-induced charge transfer between the interfaces of Ni(OH)2 and MoS2 was conducted using a FEM (as show in Fig. 5 a). The combination of MoS2 nanosheet and Ni(OH)2 was utilized. Upon the application of 3.5% strain, voltage distribution occurred as the piezopotential generated an electric field in MoS2. Vp + and Vp − represented the positive and negative piezopotential, respectively. After the transfer of charges took place, electrons migrated from Ni(OH)2 to MoS2. The plots of piezopotential and strain percentage along the longitudinal direction (y axis) were presented in Fig. 5(b). The largest electric field was observed at the interface of the heterostructure. In the corresponding strain plot, a distance function was considered in the cross-section to demonstrate that the highest strain occurred at the interface. The Field Emission Microscope (FEM) results revealed that tensile strain induced piezopotential in the MoS2/Ni(OH)2 heterostructure, which acted as an electric field and caused the diffusion of electrons in different directions. The strain not only affects the electrocatalyst, but also the photocatalyst, and it changes the band gap of the photocatalyst, Yang [84] is attempting to synthesize a unique g-C6N6/SiP-GaS heterojunction as a photocatalyst. Aiming to analyze the impact of strain on the g-C6N6/SiP-GaS heterojunction, they conducted a systematic study on the electronic properties and photocatalytic activities of the catalyst under biaxial strain. The biaxial strain, denoted as ε, is defined as the ratio of the difference in lattice constants (a − a 0) to the unstrained lattice constant (a 0). Positive values of ε (>0) represent tensile strain, while negative values of ε (<0) indicate compressive strain. The range of biaxial strain selected for this study was −4% to 4%, with an increment of 1%, to examine its influence on the g-C6N6/SiP-GaS heterojunction. The variation of the band gap of the heterojunction under different biaxial strains is illustrated in Fig. 5(c). It can be observed that the band gap value of the g-C6N6/SiP-GaS heterojunction generally decreases as the biaxial strain is applied from −4% to 4%, except for larger compressive strains. The maximum band gap value is observed under a biaxial strain of −3%. It is worth noting that lattice distortion of the catalyst occurs at higher strains. Interestingly, under biaxial strain, the conduction band minimum (CBM) of the heterojunction remains relatively unchanged, indicating that the change in band gap is primarily due to the valence band maximum (VBM). The VBM of the heterojunction gradually increases starting from a strain of −3%, resulting in a decrease in the band gap value. Furthermore, the CBM of the heterojunction reaches its maximum value under a strain of 4%, which not only enhances the catalytic activity to some extent but also facilitates water splitting in the heterojunction under different pH conditions. 3.1.3 Epitaxial growth induced strain Epitaxial Growth is a material growth technique used for depositing thin films or growing crystals on a crystal substrate. During the epitaxial growth process, the deposited or grown material has the same lattice structure and crystallographic orientation as the substrate. However, in cases where the deposited or grown material has a different lattice structure and crystallographic orientation from the substrate, this will result in strain and consequently influence the electronic structure of the catalyst [85]. Qiu [86] successfully introduced lattice strain into the heterostructure of transition metal compounds through a simple method, without the need for other factors such as heterogeneous atoms or substrates. Firstly, they uniformly anchored NiSe nanorods onto nickel foam as precursor catalysts using a one-step hydrothermal method. Subsequently, the NiSe (NS) nanorods were activated and underwent partial reconstruction into highly crystalline NiOOH under appropriate oxidation-reduction potentials. With the electrochemical redox reaction progressed, epitaxial growth of layered NiOOH continued on the surface of the original NiSe nanorods, resulting in the formation of a nano-flower-like structure resembling hydrangea. The strong interaction between crystalline NiOOH and NS created interfacial stress, significantly enhancing the adsorption capability of the catalyst surface with respect to the oxidation reaction intermediates. They found that the characteristic peak corresponding to the (001) plane of NiOOH undergoes a significant shift to a larger angle, and the interlayer spacing of the (001) plane (as shown in Fig. 5e) decreases from 4.83 Å to 4.76 Å. This indicates the generation of strain, which is caused by lattice mismatch. Specifically, the NiSe nanorods phase at the interface experiences approximately 1.35% tensile strain, while the NiOOH phase undergoes approximately 1.5% compressive strain. Previous research has confirmed that lattice strain can effectively modify interatomic distances [87], thereby altering the lattice spacing and influencing the electronic and geometric structure of the active center. Therefore, tuning the microstructure through lattice strain can ultimately optimize the electrocatalytic activity of the material. They observed a significant increase in the intensity of the peak corresponding to the O-H bond in the high-resolution O 1s spectrum of NS/NOOH-30, compared to NS/NOOH-1, indicating the hydroxylation/oxidation of the catalyst (as shown in Fig. 5f). Core/shell nanocatalysts are also a form of extension design, and researchers have developed core/shell nanocatalysts based on Ir, which exhibit excellent catalytic activity [88,89]. However, the exact mechanism behind this enhancement remains unclear. This is mainly because these core/shell nanocatalysts involve two intertwined mechanisms, namely the ligand effect and strain effect [90,91]. It is difficult to determine which effect is truly effective, especially when they have opposing contributions to the electrochemical processes, which further exacerbates the problem [92,93]. To address this issue, Li [94] published a study on the precise synthesis of PdCu/Ir core/shell nanocrystals. This catalyst possesses a unique strain effect that greatly enhances the OER. They achieved this by heteroepitaxially coating four atomic layers of Ir onto PdCu nanoparticles, resulting in a relatively thick Ir shell that effectively eliminates the ligand effect. At the same time, this coating also introduces a compressive strain of approximately 3.60%. High crystallinity and the presence of the (111) plane of fcc PdCu are confirmed by the corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) pattern, as shown in the inset of Fig. 5(g). Under HAADF-STEM mode, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping reveals that the Ir species exhibit surface segregation, while the Pd and Cu species are uniformly distributed throughout the entire core of the nanocrystal, providing direct evidence for the formation of the core/shell structure, as depicted in Fig. 5(h). The EDS line scan image demonstrates a strong correlation with Ir traces located at the edges, while Pd and Cu traces are concentrated at the center, as depicted in Fig. 5(i). The thickness of the Ir shell on the surface is estimated to be 0.8 nm, corresponding to approximately 4 atomic layers. According to the Vegard law, the lattice constant of the Pd26Cu65 core can be calculated to be 2.14 Å, while that of the Ir shell is 2.22 Å. The interfacial lattice mismatch between the PdCu core and Ir shell induces the accommodated compressive strain of 3.60%, In contrast, unlike the PdCu/Ir core/shell nanocrystals where Ir atoms are segregated on the surface, the trimetallic PdCuIr alloys with a perfect fcc crystalline structure exhibit a random occupation of Pd, Cu, and Ir, which significantly minimizes the strain. 3.1.4 Modulation induced strain Morphology is closely related to lattice strain, which is influenced by the anisotropic nature of nano polyhedral geometries and size. The controlled synthesis of nanocrystals with specific shapes can result in unique configurations that deviate significantly from the classical Wulff construction, leading to the formation of high surface energy facets, vertices, and edges. Due to their under-coordinated properties, the surface atoms at vertices and edges require stabilization through inward displacement, creating a strain gradient. This phenomenon results in distinct areas for surface interactions and, consequently, distinctive catalytic behaviors [95]. Similarly, variations in particle size can also alter the dangling surface atoms and strain gradient. Based on this principle, Scardi et al. [96] revealed the correlation between crystal shape and strain by simulating X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) of nanocrystal morphologies with different structures (as shown in Fig. 6 a–d). The study demonstrated that nanocrystals with different shapes exhibit subtle satellite peak differences at the base of the main diffraction peaks, resulting in varying degrees of strain in different structures. Ulvestad combined experimental and simulation approaches using coherent X-ray diffractive imaging (CXDI) to analyze strain in catalysts. The experimental setup is illustrated in Fig. 6(e), and the physical representation of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 6(f). The calculated strain in the β-phase nanocube is depicted in Fig. 6(g). Fig. 6(h and i) illustrate the strain generated in nanoparticles due to twinned structures [97]. Additionally, Yang et al. [65] obtained the strain fields on the surfaces of icosahedral and octahedral Pt nanocrystals with a diameter of 10 nm. Fig. 6(j and k) demonstrates that the icosahedral nanoparticles exhibit an average tensile strain of +1.6%, while the octahedral nanoparticles show an average compressive strain of −1.6%. These differences in strain can lead to various effects on catalytic activity. 3.1.5 Particle size induced strain It is generally believed that the surface atomic coordination and electronic structure of nanoparticles are size-dependent. Specifically, as the surface area to volume ratio increases, the surface strain effect on nanoparticles also increases, leading to a compression of atomic arrangement to minimize the surface energy [95]. The correlation between strain and particle size can be described by the Gibbs-Thomson equation [99]. (5) μ R - μ ∞ = 2 γ Ω R In this Eq. (5), μ(R) and µ(∞) represent the molar free energies of a particle with a radius of R and the bulk, respectively. The term γ denotes the surface free energy of the atom, and Ω is the bulk volume of the atom. Essentially, the nanoparticle aims to reduce its surface energy for improved stability. As the particle size decreases, the surface energy term increases, leading the nanoparticle to compress itself to compensate for this increase. Based on this principle, Han [100] conducted research on corrosion-resistant multiphase Ni3Al-based intermetallic alloy as an OER electrocatalyst. They aimed to enhance the oxidation by performing high-temperature annealing followed by acid treatment. The high-temperature annealing process can adjust the size of g 0 precipitates, thereby obtaining strain effects caused by g/g 0 lattice mismatch to enhance the OER activity. Electrochemical specific surface area (ECSA) was estimated from the experimental data in Fig. 7 (a–f), the ECSA value of the N-1160 electrode was the highest, indicating a larger active surface area, consistent with the smallest g 0 precipitate size. For the N-1160 sample, the average size of cuboidal g0 precipitates was only 0.36 mm, smaller than that of the other samples, resulting in increased g/g 0 boundaries. As analyzed, the lattice-mismatch between the g/g 0 interface caused strain, which could affect the movement of the d-band center and modify the adsorption of reaction intermediates, ultimately determining the catalytic performance. 3.1.6 Dealloying induced strain Dealloying is often used to selectively remove the inactive components within the catalyst, aiming at inducing lattice expansion/contraction and adjusting the surface electronic structure. This process also exposes more reactive sites, leading to enhanced activity and selectivity [75,102,103]. Based on this discovery, Zhu et al. [104] reported a method using continuous deposition and selective etching to develop PtIr Janus cubic nanocages with porous, ultrathin, and asymmetric walls. These nanocages have well-defined {100} facets and a uniform size of 20 nanometers. Furthermore, they were able to precisely control the thickness and position of each metal layer within the Janus nanocages, as shown in Fig. 8 (a). Fig. 8(b) shows the TEM image of Pd@Pt nanotubes, revealing the presence of approximately three layers of Pt atoms on the surface. Fig. 8(c) displays the morphology after the deposition of an additional three layers of nanoparticles. The TEM image in Fig. 8(d) demonstrates the well-defined cubic shape of the Pt3.1L/Ir3.0L Janus nanocage with small pores on the walls. The high-angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) image in Fig. 8(e) confirms the removal of almost all Pd atoms from the core. Fig. 8(f) confirms that both the inner and outer surfaces of the nanocage terminate at {100} facets, while Fig. 8(g) shows the uniformity of the core-shell structure. Fig. 8(h) reveals the spatial separation of various metal atoms during the deposition process. Therefore, the strain effects induced by the multi-metal Janus nanocrystals can provide a wide range of metal-related catalytic functionalities [105]. Zhuang [105] an acid-base-resistant RuIrZnO x nanocatalyst using a dispersing-etching-holing strategy. The RuIrO x nano-netcage structure composed of nanowires is shown in Fig. 9 (a). HAADF-STEM (as shown in Fig. 9b) revealed that the walls of individual RuIrO x cages became rougher and more transparent after the etching treatment, forming highly porous and reticulated walls, creating a free-standing nano-netcage architecture. A significant reduction in the X-ray counts of Zn and O (as shown in Fig. 9c) indicated the successful fabrication of the nanocatalyst. Additionally, Lin and co-workers developed a novel CrO2-RuO2 solid-solution electrocatalyst using Cr-based organic framework materials through the adsorption of RuCl3 precursors combined with annealing treatment (as shown in Fig. 9d). The HRTEM image presented in Fig. 9(e) illustrated that the individual particles were composed of fine nanocrystals, with the measured lattice spacing perfectly matching the crystallographic indices. As shown in Fig. 9(f), the regional lattice disorder was attributed to the lattice strain induced by the annealing treatment. 3.2 Physical methods induced strain In general, the surface electronic properties of nanomaterials are highly responsive to mechanical strain. This sensitivity makes strain a valuable tool for controlling electrocatalysis, leading to a re-evaluation of catalyst design. So far, strain has been extensively studied for catalysis development [107–110]. However, most research introduces strain through defect engineering, construction of unmatched heterostructures, and other methods mentioned in Section 3.1. These approaches suffer from a lack of precision in strain generation. Furthermore, once catalysts are produced, the strain is fixed, making it challenging to actively tune the strain during catalysis operation. Additionally, applying strain through defects, heterostructures, and core-shell nanostructures inevitably involves ligand effects and variations in the number of active sites. Therefore, conventional strategies have limitations in establishing a clear correlation between strain and catalytic activity. To tackle these challenges, some people devised an alternative approach by introducing strain through external substrates for electrocatalysts [111]. For instance, consider 2D materials. Due to their flexible atomic thicknesses and stable in-plane atomic bonding, suitable lattice strain can adjust the energy band structure or surface electron configuration to enhance catalytic performance. For simplicity, we have classified substrate-induced strain into two types: flexible and rigid. Flexible substrates are easier to achieve minor strain effects but are not practical, while rigid substrate-induced strain is more challenging but more applicable in industrial production. 3.2.1 Flexible substrate induced strain The flexible inductive approach inherently involves creating tension through a deformable substrate and transferring it to the 2D material attached to the surface, thereby enabling controlled adjustment of orientation and deformation. Related ultrathin 2D materials such as graphene, black phosphorus, MoS2, and WS2 are strained by the implantation of these pedestals [112–114]. The octahedra of transition metal and oxygen in transition metal oxide (TMO) can be compressed, tensed, or rotated (even combined) by uniaxial or biaxial strain from substrates [115,116]. Complex oxide thin films, such as La1 − x Sr x MO3 or SrRuO3, release stress within a very thin layer through octahedra reconstruction [117–119]. Consequently, interfacial lattice mismatch cannot ideally drive to the surface, despite the extraordinary surface sensitivity of OER activity. Van der Waals heterostructures, such as mica-based ones, provide an excellent platform for flexible TMO membranes with continuous strain tunability, benefiting from the mechanical properties of the mica substrate. Importantly, the strain release can be disregarded in this setup. For this reason, Liu [120] fabricated a Van der Waals membrane of the manganite La2/3Sr1/3MnO3 (LSMO) on a mica substrate. By manipulating the curvature of the membrane, they successfully controlled the introduced strain. They found that the introduced strain is closely related to the catalytic activity. A significant enhancement in OER was observed when approximately 0.4% strain was applied. This method allows for the design of flexible TMO membranes to increase the specific surface area. Fig. 10 (a) illustrates the XRD pattern of LSMO on a flexible mica substrate. The diffraction peaks of LSMO at 38° and 40° corresponding to (104) and (006) can be observed, along with the absence of mica substrate peaks. In Fig. 10(b), the atomic force microscopy image displays the surface morphology of the LSMO membrane, revealing a dense surface structure. The root mean square surface roughness of the LSMO membrane on mica is approximately 1.3 nm. Fig. 10(c) showcases the entire sample, which can be easily bent using a tweezer. Fig. 10(d) presents a photograph of our working electrode prepared using the LSMO membrane, showing no cracks when subjected to the appropriate degree of mechanical bending. Interestingly, Liu [121] also conducted a study on the strain effect on OER in a flexible Van der Waals LNO membrane on a mica substrate. They found that both compressive and tensile strains significantly improve the OER activity, with only 0.2% compressive and tensile strains needed to enhance the performance by approximately 50%. They believe that the weakened Ni-O chemisorption and enhanced charge transfer caused by strain are responsible for the enhancement in OER activity. Fig. 10(e) illustrates the XRD pattern of the LNO/mica membrane. The top panel shows the LNO (001) diffraction peak at 41.37°, while the mica peaks are displayed in the bottom panel. In Fig. 10(f), the Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) image exhibits a uniform surface morphology and dense surface structure with a roughness of 200 pm. The corresponding elemental mapping of La, Ni, and O is depicted in Fig. 10(g), confirming the homogeneous distribution of these elements in the membrane. Furthermore, in Fig. 10(h), the flexible membrane can be easily bent using a tweezer, and no obvious mechanical damages, are observed after the appropriate degree of mechanical bending. Fig. 10(i) displays a photograph of the prepared LNO working electrode. 3.2.2 Rigid substrate induced strain Flexible substrates have higher plasticity and only require small deformations to achieve significant improvements in OER activity. They exhibit a much more sensitive response to strain compared to rigid substrates. However, rigid substrates have higher practicality and can be applied on a larger scale. By manipulating the rigid TMO heterostructures, the electron configuration of M−O octahedra can be controlled, as observed in materials such as LaCoO3, NdNiO3, and LaNiO3 [122,123]. In the traditional approach to improving catalytic activity, the enlargement of the ECSA of a catalyst through the preparation of alloy or self-supporting electrocatalysts with nanoparticle and porosity processes has been extensively studied [124]. However, this approach is not applicable to rigid substrates as their lattice ordering would be disrupted, making them incompatible with large-scale production [125,126]. If single-crystalline TMO thin films can be detached from rigid substrates, they would experience significant enhancement in practical applications [117–119]. To this reason, Wang [85] conducted a thorough investigation of single-crystalline multilayers of freestanding SRO(SrRuO3). This was achieved by dissolving their supporting SAO interlayers in water. To maximize the strain on the freestanding SRO, a cylindrical sharp feature was intentionally designed. The process of fabricating the single-layer (n = 1) cylindrical SRO (C-SRO) is illustrated in Fig. 11 (a). Initially, an SRO layer was deposited on a (001)-oriented STO substrate as a conductive connecting layer (as show in Fig. 11b–d), followed by an Sr3Al2O6(SAO) layer as the sacrificial layer. Subsequently, SRO/ BaTiO3(BTO)/SRO was grown on top of the SAO, with the upper and lower SRO layers having asymmetric thicknesses of 16 nm and 2 nm, respectively, to create an artificial strain distribution. The interfaces of SRO/STO, SRO/SAO, and SRO/BTO exhibited the expected atomic arrangement without any structural impurity phases or dislocations. Due to the water-dissolvable nature of SAO, the SRO/BTO/SRO heterostructure and the rigid SRO will separate once the sample is submerged into deionized water, as shown in Fig. 11(e). Upon complete dissolution of the SAO, the C-SROs adhere to the rigid SRO and eventually connect with the aid of the exposed surface of the rigid SRO. To create a stack of multilayer C-SRO, prior to water dissolution, we can repeatedly deposit layers of SRO/BTO/SRO/SAO heterostructures in the epitaxy process. With the dissolution in deionized water, the freestanding SRO/BTO/SRO gradually cracks and coils into the cylindrical sharp C-SRO due to the strain. 3.3 A summary of the strategy for introducing strain In summary, most of these methods mentioned above result in a disordered lattice arrangement. Specifically, these strategies affect the lattice constant of the catalyst by fine-tuning the lattice spacing to optimize the electronic structure, or by changing the d-band center of the catalyst or the adsorption energy of the intermediate species to achieve more efficient catalytic performance. In addition, we have classified the strategies for introducing strain in OER in the latest reports, which can be categorized according to physical or chemical methods. It is important to note that these methods are often not independent, meaning that multiple strategies may be simultaneously employed in the same report, contributing to the introduction of strain. Additionally, we have conducted statistical analysis on the extent of strain introduced by various strategies and their efficiency improvements, as detailed in Table S1. Furthermore, based on the data obtained, we have plotted a star chart depicting the relationship between overpotential and Tafel slope of original catalyst and improved catalyst, as shown in Figs. S1 and S2. The horizontal axis represents overpotential, while the vertical axis represents Tafel slope, indicating that catalysts closer to the origin exhibit better performance. Moreover, we have also plotted a star chart illustrating the efficiency improvements, as depicted in Fig. S3. The horizontal axis represents the efficiency improvement of overpotential, while the vertical axis represents the efficiency improvement of Tafel slope, indicating that catalysts further away from the origin demonstrate better performance. As can be seen from Fig. S2, Ru/RuO2@c, D-NiFe (Double layer hydroxide)LDH, Co3O4-Ag, Fe (Se x S1- x )2 are the most prominent, and they are all strain induced by the construction of heterojunction or element doping, this means that introducing strain by constructing heterojunction or element doping is the most efficient and convenient method. In addition, D-NiFe LDH and Ni (OH)2/MoS2 were the most effective catalysts for strain-raising, and they were also strain-induced by the strategy of constructing heterojunction. Finally, we can find that the most effective strain rate is 3%–4%, higher strain rate will lead to the collapse of the catalyst and the loss of stability. 4 The role of strain in OER After introducing the basic knowledge and introduction methods related to strain, the following will analyze the role of strain effect in OER by combining some recent reports. 4.1 Strain-induced the change of potential determining steps on OER Wen [127] discovered that the application of strains, particularly compressive strains, has a significant impact on the free energy changes involved in H2O dissociation and *OOH deprotonation during OER on SrTiO3 (001). Interestingly, tensile strains decrease the surface energy and reduce the OER overpotential by decreasing the free energy change for the rate-determining step, which is the second step of OER (*OH deprotonation). On the other hand, compressive strains increase the surface energy and the OER overpotential. Previous reports have described various reaction mechanisms for the OER. In this study, we employed a commonly used OER mechanism, which involves four Proton-Coupled Electron Transfer steps, as shown in Eqs. (6)–(9) [128,129]. The following will borrow this mechanism to analyze the effects of tensile strain and compressive strain in the OER process. (6) ∗ + 2 H 2 O l → ∗ OH + H + + e - + H 2 O l (7) H 2 O l + ∗ OH + e - + H + → ∗ O + H 2 O l + 2 ( H + + e - ) (8) H 2 O l + ∗ O + 2 ( H + + e - ) → ∗ OOH + 3 ( H + + e - ) (9) ∗ OOH + 3 ( H + + e - ) → ∗ + O 2 + 4 ( H + + e - ) Where, the symbol * represents an active site. H2O represent a liquid-phase water molecule. *O, *OH, and *OOH represent the three different adsorbed intermediates in the OER. H+ and e− represent a proton and electron, respectively. Fig. 12 (a and b) show the changes in free energy for the four steps of the OER process on the catalyst surface with and without applied strains. On the (001) surface, the deprotonation of the hydroxyl adsorbate (as shown in Eq. (7)) exhibits the highest free energy change, ΔG = 2.48 eV. The overpotential for the entire OER process is estimated to be 1.25 eV, which is in close agreement with the value reported by Liu [130]. Additionally, they found that the applied strains have a significant impact on the H2O dissociation (as shown in Eq. (6) and the *OOH deprotonation (as shown in Eq. (9)) steps, while having a moderate effect on the *OH deprotonation (as shown in Eq. (7)) and the *OOH generation (as shown in Eq. (8)) steps. Applying compressive strain makes H2O dissociation easier but O2 generation more difficult. On the other hand, tensile strain has a relatively minor effect on these four reaction steps. When a tensile strain of 0.6% is applied, the overpotential is reduced by 0.2 eV. Some studies have shown that compressive surface strain can enhance the activity of oxidation-reduction reactions, while tensile strain can promote the dissociation of water. It is important to note that the specific effects of strain on H2O dissociation and O2 generation may vary depending on the material and surface conditions. In summary, compressive strains increase the surface energy and OER overpotential, while tensile strains reduce the surface energy and OER overpotential by forming surface O–O bonds. The adsorption of OER intermediates involves pulling the surface Ti atoms out of the surface O plane, altering the structure of the bare surface, especially under compressive strains. The reaction steps of water dissociation (Eq. (6)) and *OOH deprotonation (Eq. (9)) are greatly influenced by compressive strains, as these two steps involve both adsorbed intermediates and the bare surface. However, the reaction steps of *OH deprotonation (Eq. (7)) and *OOH generation (Eq. (8)) are less affected by compressive strains, as there is minimal surface structural difference between *OH, *O, and *OOH. By applying biaxial tensile strains, Pu [131] successfully reduced the overpotentials of CoO2, FeO2, and VTe2 by over 40%. Additionally, the tensile strains altered the rate-determining step of the OER process. Fig. 12(e) shows the Gibbs free energy diagram of the adsorbed intermediates on monolayer CoO2 during the OER process. It can be observed that under biaxial tensile strain, the rate-determining step for FeO2, VSe2, and VTe2 is the third step ΔG8 (*O-*OOH). They found that without applying strain, the rate-determining step for the OER on monolayer CoO2 is the first step (H2O–*OH) with a Gibbs free energy of 1.914 eV. However, after applying biaxial strain, the rate-determining step changes to the second step (*OH–*O), with a decrease in Gibbs free energy to 1.602 eV (as shown in Fig. 12f). Fig. 12(g–j) illustrates the variation in Gibbs free energy differences (ΔGi) for the catalysts under biaxial tensile strain. It can be observed that for CoO2, except for a 4.0% biaxial strain, the rate-determining step remains the first step. For FeO2, the rate-determining step is the first step when the biaxial strain is less than 3%, but changes to the third step under larger strain values. Similarly, for VSe2 and VTe2, the rate-determining step is the third step without strain or under small biaxial tensile strains, but changes to the fourth step when the strain is larger than 6% and 5% respectively. In summary, they utilized first-principles calculations to study the binding of intermediates in the OER process for several magnetic 2D monolayers. They found that the overpotentials of CoO2, FeO2, VSe2, and VTe2 monolayers in the OER can be reduced to below 1.0 V. Specifically, under a biaxial tensile strain of 4.0% and 3.0%, the overpotentials of the CoO2 and VTe2 monolayers are reduced to 0.372 V and 0.491 V, respectively, which is attributed to the strain-induced changes in the rate-determining steps. 4.2 Strain-induced movement of the d-band center towards the Fermi level Based on the d-band center theory, appl ying tensile strain to a material will cause the d-band center of the metal atoms to shift to higher energy levels, resulting in a stronger attraction between the adsorbent and the substrate material [132]. Ma [133] conducted first-principles calculations to investigate the effect of strain induced by Pt doping on the catalytic performance of Ti2CO2 for OER and ORR. They found that Pt-doped Ti2CO2 exhibits excellent stability within the strain range of 0% to 6%. Moreover, as the tensile strain increases, the d-band center moves closer to the Fermi level, enhancing the interaction between Pt-doped Ti2CO2 and the catalytic intermediates. Additionally, Pt-doped Ti2CO2 shows a significant inhibitory effect on HER. According to a previous report, the width of the d-band in Pt directly impacts the interatomic matrix elements [134]. Applying tensile strain increases the distance between the atoms on the surface of Pt-VO-Ti2CO2, thereby reducing the interatomic matrix elements and the width of the d-band in the Pt atom. As shown in Fig. 13 (a), the broadening of the PDOS of the Pt atom's d-electron orbital decreases, while the peak of the density of states rises with increasing tensile strain. The results show that the d-band center of the Pt atom, which is initially at −1.92 eV on the unstrained Pt-VO-Ti2CO2, shifts to higher energy levels on the 1%, 2%, 3%, 4%, 5%, and 6% strained Pt-VO-Ti2CO2, as depicted in Fig. 13(b). Specifically, the d-band center values are 1.90, 1.87, 1.81, 1.74, 1.71, and 1.64 eV for the respective strain levels. In general, when the d-band center of late transition metals, such as Pt, is closer to the Fermi level, the bond strength with catalytic intermediates increases [135,136]. Therefore, it can be reasonably inferred that the binding between the catalytic intermediates and Pt-VO-Ti2CO2 will be stronger with increasing strain, potentially enhancing the catalytic activity of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 13(c–e), at 3% tensile strain, the Gibbs free energy decreases to 1.82 eV, and at 6% tensile strain, it further decreases to 1.64 eV. The application of 3% and 6% tensile strain can reduce the overpotential of the catalyst from 0.7 V (without strain) to 0.59 V and 0.41 V, respectively. 4.3 Strain-induced the spin state transition The proposal by Ren [137] is to use the SCO (spin-crossover) phenomenon in 2D metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) to control the catalytic activity in the OER process. This is achieved by designing 2D SCO MOFs with square planar coordinated Co as nodes and tetra-kis-substituted cyanimino squaric acid (TCSA) as ligands. Through first-principles calculations, it is demonstrated that applying a small compressive strain of about 2% to Co(TCSA) triggers a spin state transition from high-spin (HS) to low-spin states (LS). For Co (TCSA), there are two distinct spin states, namely the HS and LS states, as depicted in Fig. 13(j). To provide a detailed demonstration of the spin state transition in Co (TCSA), the researchers performed calculations using the PBE + U method to determine the relationship between energy and lattice constant in the two spin states, as shown in Fig. 13(f). The lattice constants of Co (TCSA) corresponding to the HS and LS states were 12.48 and 12.24 Å, respectively, indicating that the SCO can be easily induced by applying external strain. Furthermore, the LS state is slightly more stable than the HS state, with an energy difference of 0.04 eV. To further validate the SCO in Co (TCSA), hybrid functional HSE06 calculations were also conducted, yielding qualitatively similar results. There have been some reports on the strain-induced spin state transitions.The electronic structure of CoOOH is described using a theoretical model based on ligand field theory. In an octahedral field, such as in LaCoO3, Co3+ exhibits three spin states: low spin ( t 2 g 6 e g 0 , S = 0), intermediate spin ( t 2 g 5 e g 1 , S = 1), and high spin ( t 2 g 4 e g 2 , S = 2). However, in the ground state of CoOOH, Co3+ tends to adopt the low-spin configuration ( t 2 g 6 e g 0 ) due to the higher crystal field splitting energy compared to the electron pairing energy. This results in fully occupied t2g orbitals of Co3+, leading to low electron transfer conductivity and a significant rate-limiting step in the formation of adsorbed *OOH species. To this reason, using density functional theory (DFT), Li [138] conducted a study to examine the impact of strain engineering on the electronic structure and catalytic performance of two-dimensional (2D) CoOOH, as well as the underlying mechanism of the OER. The findings reveal that strain engineering proves to be an effective method for modifying the electronic configuration of Co3+ ions in CoOOH. Specifically, under a tensile strain of 9%, the electronic configuration of Co3+ ions can be transformed from a low spin (LS: t 2 g 6 e g 0 ) state to a high spin (HS: t 2 g 4 e g 2 ) state. The energy barriers along the reaction pathway were computed (Fig. 7b–d). In the case of LS CoOOH (as show in Fig. 13g), the energy barriers for the four electrochemical steps are 1.41, 1.89, 1.39, and −1.12 eV, respectively. The nucleophilic attack of OH− on Co-O species (*O/*OOH) is identified as the potential-determining reaction step (PDS) with an energy barrier of 1.89 eV. For HS CoOOH (as show in Fig. 13h and i), the energy barriers for the four electrochemical steps are 1.76, 0.99, 0.73, and 1.51 eV for the A site, and 1.55, 1.73, 0.97, and 0.64 eV for the B site. The PDSs in both cases involve the formation of the *OOH intermediate, with energy barriers of 1.76 and 1.73 eV, and overpotentials of 0.53 and 0.50 V for sites A and B, respectively. Additionally, the O2 desorption energy is determined to be 1.35 eV for LS CoOOH, which is consistent with experimental findings. 4.4 Strain-induced the reconstruction of highly active species TMO serve as precursors for electrocatalysts, and typically when a positive potential is applied, the real active material for OER is generated through the partial dissolution of metallic cations and simultaneous reconstruction of residual cations on the surface. By strain engineering of heterogeneous interfaces, the generation of active species can also be facilitated. CMO(CoMoO4·0.69H2O) nanosheets are sequentially synthesized onto Co3O4 needles by Yin [139], which serve as a rigid electrochemical support for adjustable strain during surface reconstruction. The lattice strain of CoMoO4·0.69H2O in CoMoO4·0.69H2O/Co3O4 is utilized as a tool to customize oxygen evolution and its reversible characteristics. This study presents a significant approach to manipulate the intrinsic and reversible catalytic properties of transition metal oxides through strain engineering of heterogeneous interfaces. The lattice strain in CMO plays a crucial role in facilitating the dissolution of molybdenum, allowing more Co2+ cations to react with OH− and form CoOOH at a lower potential. In the case of dm-15-CMO, the transformation into CoOOH occurs at a higher potential due to the higher proportion of thick CMO compared to Co3O4 needles (as show in Fig. 14 a and b). If dm-15-CMO is maintained under 1.0 V vs. RHE for a certain period, more CoOOH is generated along with increased molybdenum dissolution. In this scenario, a CoOOH vibration peak at 500 cm−1 is also observed (as show in Fig. 14c and d). Based on the results from LSV curves (as show in Fig. 14e) and Tafel slope (as show in Fig. 14f), it can be observed that the overpotential and Tafel slope initially decrease with the synthesizing duration up to 4 hours, followed by an increase up to 15 hours. These two parameters are highly influenced by the lattice strain in CMOs. Notably, dm-4-CMO demonstrates the lowest overpotential (at 100 mA cm−2) of 280 mV and a Tafel slope of 82.89 mV dec−1, showing a decline of approximately 10.71% and 17.04% compared to dm-1-CMO, respectively. The observed low overpotential (at 100 mA cm−2) of dm-4-CMO is significantly lower than that of previously reported CMO electrocatalysts. Chen [140] also discovered that the introduction of strain energy can promote the transformation of the active phase. He proposed a method utilizing molten salt with bound water is proposed, which allows for the construction of abundant D-NiFe LDH. In situ characterizations further confirm that dislocations have a significant impact on the generation of the active phase and the electronic structure. During the voltage increases from 0 to 1.35 V, there is no noticeable change in the Raman spectra of C-NiFe LDH and D-NiFe LDH. However, when the applied potentials slightly increased to 1.41 and 1.43 V, the intensity of peaks at 453 and 530 cm−1 in D-NiFe LDH gradually decreased, eventually disappearing at 1.43 V. On the other hand, the peak in C-NiFe LDH showed a slight decrease at 1.43 V and completely vanished at 1.47 V. This process can be attributed to the reconstruction of NiFe LDH, where the crystalline surface is broken, leading to the formation of Ni(OH) x species and preparing the formation of NiOOH. With further increase in potential, two new peaks seemed to appear, indicating differences in the formation of new peaks. Specifically, D-NiFe LDH exhibited the new peaks at 1.45 V, while C-NiFe LDH showed the new peaks at 1.49 V. The lower potential requirement for D-NiFe LDH suggests an easier transformation process. This may be due to the strain field produced by dislocation and the tensile strain providing the formation energy for highly oxidative NiOOH species. Previous works have shown that highly oxidative NiOOH species are the active phase of the OER process. Aiming to confirm the influence of lattice strain and dislocation on the generation of the active phase and alterations, further experiments have been conducted. As shown in Fig. 14(g), D-NiFe LDH exhibited superior OER activity compared to C-NiFe LDH, indicating that the introduced strain has a positive effect on the OER. Specifically, D-NiFe LDH achieved a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a potential of 203 mV, which is significantly lower than that of C-NiFe LDH (223 mV) and Ni Foam (343 mV). The Tafel slope, which reflects catalysis kinetics, is summarized in Fig. 14(h and i). The D-NiFe LDH (5.7 mV dec−1) exhibited the lowest Tafel slope among the samples tested. The decrease in the Tafel slope suggests an enhancement in reaction kinetics, confirming the role of strain and dislocation in improving the reconstruction of highly active species. 4.5 Strain-induced the charge transfer Grain boundaries in heterogeneous structures offer distinct advantages for electrocatalytic activity. They not only regulate electron transfer at heterogeneous interfaces through appropriate material combinations but also optimize the chemisorption of reaction intermediates [141,142]. Introducing defect structures such as lattice strain, edge vacancies, and dislocations significantly influences the electronic states and atomic configurations near defects [143,144], leading to a change in the coordination environment of the active sites [145–148]. Chen [149] demonstrated the synthesis of flexible nanosheets composed of ultra-thin carbon shell-coated Ru/RuO2 nanoparticles with abundant grain boundaries. This was achieved through molecule-assisted pyrolysis followed by an oxidation strategy. The experimental findings provide systematic evidence that the carbon layer, which possesses excellent electrical conductivity, serves as a protective barrier against the dissolution of Ru/RuO2 and improves the stability of the catalyst. The presence of grain boundaries within the core-shell structure enhances the catalytic activity of the catalyst. Additionally, the lattice strain at the grain boundaries, whether compressed or stretched, facilitates faster electron transport at the electrode/electrolyte interface. This, in turn, creates more active sites for the OER. Ru/RuO2@C-300 exhibits remarkably high catalytic activity and long-term stability for the OER in acidic media. It only requires a low overpotential of 173 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2, and it maintains its stability for 120 hours in the acidic electrolyte. Experimental results have shown that the exceptional electrocatalytic performance of Ru/RuO2@C-300 can be attributed to the synergistic effect of its abundant internal grain boundaries, lattice defects, and ultra-thin carbon shell coating. These factors provide increased exposure to active sites and high electrical conductivity. 4.6 Strain-induced the generation of defects The introduction of strain can generate various types of defects, which in turn create more active sites, thereby accelerating the electrocatalytic reaction [150]. For the first time, Jing [151] successfully synthesized the Fe(Se x S1− x )2 catalysts using a one-pot hydrothermal reaction. By adjusting the mole ratios of Se and S, they prepared different Fe (Se x S1− x )2 catalysts. The presence of S and Se elements in the catalyst composition allows for the creation of lattice strain and lattice mismatch. As a result, the electronic structure is optimized, leading to the exposure of more active sites. Compared to single-component FeSe2 and FeS catalysts, the Fe (Se x S1− x )2 catalysts exhibit enhanced electrochemical activities for OER. Fig. 14(j) shows the linear sweep voltammetry curves of various catalysts including Fe (Se x S1− x )2 and IrO2, the Fe (Se0.5S0.5)2 catalyst exhibits an OER onset potential of 1.44 V vs. RHE, confirming the superior OER performance of the Fe (Se0.5S0.5)2 catalyst. This can be attributed to the appropriate S/Se ratio in the multicomponent Fe (Se x S1− x )2 catalysts, which induces lattice strain and lattice defects, exposing more structural defect sites. Fig. 14(k), the Tafel slope value of Fe (Se0.5S0.5)2 is fitted to be 54 mV dec−1, indicating rapid OER kinetics on the Fe (Se0.5S0.5)2 surface. These electrochemical data demonstrate that the introduction of S, causing lattice strain and lattice defects, can enhance the electrochemical activities for OER. 4.7 The synergy between ligand effect and strain effect Alloying leads to changes in various catalytic properties, including the core structure, lattice distance, surface chemical properties, chemical composition of the ensemble, and surface atomic coordination, thereby significantly impacting the activity and stability of the catalysts [152]. Among these property changes, three factors have the most significant influence: (1) the strain effect, which involves altering the lattice distance of the core; (2) the ligand effect, which involves modifying the chemical properties of the atoms on the surface; and (3) the ensemble effect, which involves changing the catalytic properties of an ensemble of atoms on the surface [153,154]. In actual alloy catalysts, these three effects are often intertwined, making it challenging to distinguish them individually. Based on the d-band theory, a lower electron density on the catalyst's surface near the Fermi level leads to weaker adsorption with the adsorbate. This occurs because electrons near the Fermi level migrate to the adsorbate during bond formation [155]. Seung-hoon Kim [156], their calculations showed that the d-band occupancy near the Fermi level (χF) decreases due to strain and ligand effects. Specifically, the ligand effect significantly reduces the electron density near the Fermi level [χF(Pt(111) = 0.089 → χF(Pt3Ni/Pt) = 0.084 → χF(Pt3Ni/Ptskin) = 0.061)]. Furthermore, when compared to Pt(111), the OER and ORR activities in a Pt3Ni/Ptskin catalyst with a Pt skin layer were boosted by 13.7% and 18.4% correspondingly, owing to the strain and ligand effects. 4.8 A summary of the role of strain This chapter reviews the effect of strain, which can change the center position of the d-band, change the potential determining step and change the spin state by regulating the intermediate binding energy, and can accelerate electron transfer and generate defects. In addition, many times there will be several synergies, and it is difficult to distinguish which of them is the most important contribution. For example, the introduction of strain changes the adsorption energy of the intermediate, so that the determination rate of OER changes. In addition, according to Table S1, several reports have concluded that 6% strain introduction ratio is the best through DFT calculation, and we have mentioned in part 3.3 that many experiments have reached the conclusion that 3%–4% strain introduction ratio is the best, which may mean that the theoretical calculation needs further optimization. 5 Conclusions and outlook This review provides an overview of the relevant theoretical knowledge of strain in OER and introduces the ways to introduce strain. Strain is categorized into physical and chemical methods, and its functions are discussed. DFT can effectively calculate the appropriate proportion of intermediate species in catalytic reactions and guide the adjustment of the adsorption performance of existing catalysts, thereby optimizing catalytic performance. However, there are still some ambiguous issues in OER and strain, such as the appropriate proportion of strain to be introduced and its correlation. How do compressive and tensile strains contribute to OER? Why do some studies believe that biaxial strain has more advantages than uniaxial strain, and to what extent? Does the introduction of strain enhance the stability of the catalyst or does it decrease it? In addition, there are other issues that need to be addressed, which will be discussed in the following text. (1) The contribution of compressive strain and tensile strain to OER: Wen [127] proposed that tensile strain promotes OER, while compressive strain inhibits OER. Compressive strains increase the surface energy and OER overpotential, while tensile strains reduce the surface energy and OER overpotential by forming a surface O–O bond. The adsorption of OER intermediates alters the structure of the bare surface, particularly under compressive strains, pulling the surface Ti atom out of the surface O plane. As a result, the reaction steps of H2O dissociation and *OOH deprotonation are significantly affected by compressive strains, as these steps involve both adsorbed intermediates and the bare surface. However, the reaction steps of *OH deprotonation and *OOH generation are moderately affected due to the relatively small difference in surface structure among *OH, *O, and *OOH. Therefore, to achieve better OER performance, it is preferable to introduce tensile strains rather than compressive strains during the synthetic process of SrTiO3. On the contrary, Wang [157] believes that compressive strain promotes OER, while tensile strain inhibits OER. They also analyzed this issue from the perspective of adsorption of intermediates. They found that the integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population values of Rh-H interaction under e = +2%, 0%, and −5% are +2.45, +2.22, and +1.97, respectively, while the integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population values of Rh-OH interaction with the strain of +2%, 0%, and −5% are +1.96, +1.77, and +1.51, respectively. The strain effect on Rh-BHT can be concluded, indicating that tensile strain weakens the binding of reactive intermediates, while compressive strain results in stronger binding. In addition, Gao found that compressive strain results in strong interactions between the H* or oxygen intermediates and the corresponding active site, partly due to the serious distortion of the 2D structure induced by surface compressive strain during the processes of *H or oxygen species adsorption. In contrast, the adsorption-desorption energetics toward *H and oxygen species can be finely tuned within the ranges of applied tensile strain. Therefore, it is not possible to generalize the effects of compressive or tensile strain on OER, as it varies for different catalysts. This depends on their intermediate adsorption energy, and stronger adsorption energy is not necessarily better (as illustrated by the volcano plot). With the normal circumstances, tensile strain elevates the d-band center and the antibond d state, thereby enhancing the interaction between the catalyst and adsorbate. In contrast, compressive strain broadens the d-band center, resulting in increased occupation of the antibond orbitals and weakening the adsorption strength of the reaction intermediates. Furthermore, this influence will further affect the rate-determining step of the reaction, and only in the end can it be determined whether compressive or tensile strain contributes positively to OER. (2) The proportion of strain addition is also related to the adsorption energy of the catalyst intermediate. Usually, the best catalytic performance is obtained when the strain addition ratio is 1%–4%. For example, SCO MOFs prepared by Ren [3] perform best at a strain addition ratio of 2%, while GeC nanosheets prepared by Yin [158] perform best at a strain addition ratio of 3%. When the ratio is larger, anomalies are observed at tensile strains of 5% and 6%, leading to significant lattice expansion, elongation of Ti–O and Sr–O bonds, surface chemical bond rearrangement, and reduced symmetry [127]. As a result, the surface energy is further reduced, leading to a decrease in catalytic performance. However, this is not absolute. For instance, metal-benzenhexathiolate prepared by Wang [157] undergoes severe lattice distortion when the compressive strain is reduced from 5% to 3%, making the structure unstable. This catalyst performs best at a strain addition ratio of 1% under tensile strain. Additionally, for photocatalytic heterogeneous catalysts, the proportion of strain addition can also affect the catalytic performance by changing the band gap value. Yang [86] demonstrated that a biaxial strain of 4% can effectively enhance all light absorption, OER, and HER of the g-C6N6/SiP-GaS heterojunction. In short, the separation of photogenerated carriers, appropriate band edges, and strong visible light absorption make the designed g-C6N6/SiP-GaS heterojunction a promising water-splitting photocatalyst. For some flexible substrates, such as the Flexible Van der Waals Manganite Membrane, a small proportion of strain addition, approximately around 0.2%, can achieve excellent catalytic effects [120,121]. (3) Uniaxial strain is the strain applied in one direction, while biaxial strain is the strain applied simultaneously in two directions. Biaxial strain can lead to a more complex strain state, which may have a more significant impact on electron transfer, intermediate adsorption energy, bond length, and bond angle in electrochemical processes [80,159,160].
