The relationship between strain and stability is somewhat ambiguous. Gao [80] found that the stability of Co@N1-GY decreases with increasing lattice strain. As the strain changes from compressive to tensile, the C–Co bond length increases linearly, and the p-band center of C atoms and the d-band center of Co atoms are linearly upshifted. Lin [161] proposed an anisotropic auxetic Janus 2D photocatalyst, a structurally stable ε-SnO monolayer, using first-principles calculations. The monolayer ε-SnO exhibits extraordinary flexibility due to its ultralow Young's moduli and high critical crack strain. (4) It should be noted that from the way strain is introduced to the effects it causes, they are not isolated, and sometimes they can be coupled together and have synergistic effects. For example, doping of impurities can sometimes form heterogeneous structures, which we may not have noticed, and epitaxial growth can also be considered as a form of heterogeneous structure or doping of impurities to some extent. Changes in the adsorption energy of intermediate species caused by strain, the movement of the d-band center, and the changes in the rate-determining steps often occur simultaneously, and we should not consider them separately. This also brings a new question of which factor is the most important, and this question requires our contemplation and resolution. (5) In order to detect strain, we require more advanced operation/in situ characterization techniques. Presently, there are several methods accessible for strain detection, including X-ray absorption fine structure, X-ray absorption spectroscopy, X-ray absorption near-edge structure, 4D scanning transmission electron microscopy, annular dark field detector, and others. Nonetheless, these methods are unable to offer a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental reaction mechanisms. The study of reaction mechanisms is constrained without sufficiently precise and advanced characterization techniques. Therefore, we necessitate additional in situ characterization techniques to uncover the interactions among various intermediates, metal sites, and highly active species. (6) While the use of d-band theory and DFT has provided some understanding of how the introduction of strain can impact catalytic activity through the alteration of intermediate adsorption, we believe that DFT remains underutilized and has untapped potential to offer unique insights not available through experiments alone. There is a need to further explore the capabilities of DFT and its integration with experimental methods to evaluate additional aspects, such as achieving uniform and stable strain in catalysts and distinguishing the primary effects among various synergistic interactions. (7) From Table S1, it can be found that many work introduced strain, paid attention to the effect of strain, but did not pay attention to the strain introduction ratio, and did not use the theoretical calculation, which means that their catalysts can also use the theoretical calculation to find the most appropriate strain introduction ratio and then carry out more subtle regulation to achieve the best catalytic performance. (8) For strain engineering, element doping or heterojunction construction is efficient, but most of the time they can only stay in the laboratory for small-scale exploration and cannot be large-scale industrial mass production. For industrial mass production, it is necessary to start from the substrate. Section 3.2 provides some latest work related to the substrate, but it can be seen in Table S1 that their performance and stability are not excellent, which requires more exploration. Zihang Feng received his bachelor‘s degree from the School of Materials Science and Engineering of North University of China and is now studying for a master‘s degree in the research group of Professor Liu Xuanwen from the School of Materials Engineering of North eastern University of China. At present, he is committed to the research of OER, and is interested in transition metal-based inverse spinel catalysts, such as NiFe2O4, and is also studying the effect of external field on OER. Chuanlin Dai was born in Sichuan Province, China. He received his bachelor’s degree from Shenyang Ligong University, China in 2022.Currently, he is studying towards a master’s degree in Northeastern University under the supervision of Professor Xuanwen Liu. His current research interests are focused on the development of new schemes for the synthesis of novel graphitic carbon nitride photo-Fenton catalysts and the further exploration of its latest photo-Fenton catalytic mechanism. Zhe Zhang received his bachelor's degree from the School of Materials Science and Engineering of North University of China.Now he is studying for a master's degree in the research group of Professor Liu Xuanwen from the School of Materials Engineering of North-eastern University of China. He devoted himself to OER research and is interested transition metal-based catalysts. At present, he is also studying the effect of magnetic fields on catalytic mechanisms. Xuefei Lei graduated from Northeastern University in 2009 and received her Ph.D. She is now a master's supervisor at Northeastern University. She has published more than 30 papers, of which more than 20 are SCI and EI searches, and has authorized 3 national invention patents. Her main research interests include the comprehensive utilization of secondary resources and environmental protection, the preparation and application of photocatalytic water purification materials and so on. Wenning Mu received her PhD from Northeastern University in 2009. She is a member of the Physical Chemistry Branch of Metallurgical Process of the Chinese Society of Metals, a member of the Chinese Society of Non-Ferrous Metals, an expert in correspondence review of the National Natural Science Foundation, a national undergraduate thesis sampling review expert, and a special editorial board member of Metals. Journal of Cleaner Production, Separation and Purification Technology, Transaction of Nonferrous Metals Society China, Minerals Engineering, Hydrometallurgy and other international journals reviewer. Rui Guo received her Ph.D. from Northeastern University in 2009 and currently teaches at Northeastern University as an associate professor and doctoral supervisor. He is a reviewer of international SCI journals such as <Journal of Alloys and Compounds>, <Applied Surface Science> and <ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces>. She is currently committed to the research of catalytic oxidation, adsorption precipitation,photocatalyticmaterials and photoelectrocatalytic materials. Xuanwen Liu received his Ph.D. from Tsinghua University in 2004 and currently teaches at Northeastern University as a professor and doctoral supervisor. In the past five years, as the person in charge, he presided over one project of National Natural Science Fund general project, one key project of business expenses of central universities-national defense pre-research, two provincial and ministerial-level projects, five projects above the municipal level and horizontal projects, with research funds of over 1 million yuan, published more than 30 related papers and authorized 15 patents. Junhua You received his Ph.D. degree in Materials Science from Northeastern University in 2009. After that he worked as a teacher in Shenyang University of Technology. Now,he is a full professor of materials science. His research interests focus on the preparation,characterization of advanced functional composites and metastable materials and their applications in engineering, environment and energy fields, the theory of metal solidification and the research of new materials of casting alloys.

coredata.dc:description: The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a crucial step in metal-air batteries and water splitting technologies, playing a significant role in the efficiency and achievable heights of these two technologies. However, the OER is a four-step, four-electron reaction, and its slow kinetics result in high overpotentials, posing a challenge. To address this issue, numerous strategies involving modified catalysts have been proposed and proven to be highly efficient. In these strategies, the introduction of strain has been widely reported because it is generally believed to effectively regulate the electronic structure of metal sites and alter the adsorption energy of catalyst surfaces with reaction intermediates. However, strain has many other effects that are not well known, making it an important yet unexplored area. Based on this, this review provides a detailed introduction to the various roles of strain in OER. To better explain these roles, the review also presents the definition of strain and elucidates the potential mechanisms of strain in OER based on the d-band center theory and adsorption volcano plot. Additionally, the review showcases various ways of introducing strain in OER through examples reported in the latest literature, aiming to provide a comprehensive perspective for the development of strain engineering. Finally, the review analyzes the appropriate proportion of strain introduction, compares compressive and tensile strain, and examines the impact of strain on stability. And the review offers prospects for future research directions in this emerging field.
